Abstract: Chief Justice William H Rehnquist's annual report on state of federal judiciary expresses satisfaction that vacancies on US Sentencing Commission have been filled, that cost-of-living adjustments are being made to judges' salaries and that case loads grew only modestly after sharp increases in recent years; criticizes 'unnecessary federalization of traditional state law matters'; asks Congress to provide higher pay for lawyers who are appointed to represent indigent defendants (M)
Snippet: Chief Justice William H Rehnquist's annual report on state of federal judiciary expresses satisfaction that vacancies on US Sentencing Commission have been filled, that cost-of-living adjustments are being made to judges' salaries and that case lo...
LeadParagraph: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist surveyed the state of the federal judiciary today and, in contrast to many of his 13 previous year-end reports, pronounced himself quite pleased.

Headline.Main: Chief Justice's Annual Report Notes Progress in the Judiciary
Headline.PrintHeadline: Chief Justice's Annual Report Notes Progress in the Judiciary
